sub_topic: Finding the slope of a tangent line to a curve
message_1: Find the slope of the tangent line to the curve of y = 2x^3 - 5x^2 + 3x - 1 at x = 2.
message_2:
To find the slope of the tangent line to the curve at a given point, we need to find the derivative of the function with respect to x, and then evaluate it at the given x-value.

The function is y = 2x^3 - 5x^2 + 3x - 1.

First, find the derivative dy/dx:
dy/dx = d(2x^3 - 5x^2 + 3x - 1)/dx
dy/dx = 6x^2 - 10x + 3

Now, evaluate the derivative at x = 2:
dy/dx(2) = 6(2)^2 - 10(2) + 3
dy/dx(2) = 6(4) - 20 + 3
dy/dx(2) = 24 - 20 + 3
dy/dx(2) = 7

The slope of the tangent line to the curve at x = 2 is 7.
